case_vignette: A 14-hour-old boy has failed to pass stool and is vomiting greenish fluid. He was born at 40 weeks gestation with no complications during delivery or pregnancy. His temperature is 97.6°F (36.4°C), blood pressure is 64/34 mmHg, pulse is 140/min, respirations are 33/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The child is currently breastfeeding and appears irritable. Physical exam is notable for a distended and non-tender abdomen. Rectal exam is unremarkable. An abdominal radiograph is shown in Figure A.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I haven't been able to pass stool since I was born, and I've been vomiting a greenish fluid.
Have you been able to urinate?
Yes, I have been able to urinate.
Have you been experiencing any abdominal pain or discomfort?
My belly appears swollen, but I'm not showing any signs of pain when it's touched.
Have you been experiencing any fever or chills?
No, I don't have a fever or chills.
Have you been born prematurely?
No, I was born at full term, 40 weeks gestation.
Have you been breastfed or given formula?
I am currently breastfeeding.
Have you been given any medications or supplements?
No, I haven't been given any medications or supplements.
Have you been given any vaccinations recently?
No, I have not received any vaccinations yet.
Have you been born to a family with a history of medical conditions?
There were no complications during pregnancy or delivery mentioned.
Final Diagnosis: Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

No problem, thank you for sharing that information. Based on the symptoms you've described, it's possible that your baby may have a condition called necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). NEC is a serious condition that can occur in premature babies, and it can cause the intestines to become inflamed and damaged. It's important to seek medical attention immediately if you suspect your baby may have NEC.
